content: The "POWER Act" aims to address high rates of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking by providing pro bono legal services to vulnerable individuals. Studies show that 25% of women experience domestic violence in their lifetime, highlighting the need for proactive measures at all levels to combat this issue. According to the National Network to End Domestic Violence, over 10,000 requests for services were not met in one day in September 2014. Pro bono legal assistance can help by providing access to shelter, transportation, and childcare, reducing the likelihood of future violence. Legal representation increases the likelihood of obtaining a protective order, as demonstrated by a study showing 83% success rate with an attorney compared to 32% without. The American Bar Association emphasizes the responsibility of lawyers to provide legal services to those in need, highlighting the rewarding experience of helping the disadvantaged. Leaders in the legal community, such as judges, play a crucial role in supporting these efforts. District courts should encourage lawyers to provide pro bono resources to help victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking escape the cycle of abuse. This will inspire others to join the cause and raise awareness of these issues nationwide. Communities offering pro bono legal services and support to survivors empower them to move forward with their lives. The chief judge in each judicial district will lead public events promoting pro bono legal services for survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. This includes districts with Indian tribes or tribal organizations. Each chief judge must lead public events promoting pro bono legal services for survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking in partnership with Indian tribes or tribal organizations to increase access to these services. They have discretion in organizing these events to maximize local impact and access to high-quality legal services. Reporting requirements to the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts must be met by October 30 of each year. Each chief judge must lead public events promoting pro bono legal services for survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking in partnership with Indian tribes or tribal organizations. Reporting requirements to the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts must be met by October 30 of each year. The Director shall then compile and summarize the reports for Congress by January 1, including an analysis of how each event aligns with the goals of the Act and suggestions for improvement. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts will utilize existing funds to implement the Act's requirements.
